item.title: Coronavirus: Plan dropped for all primary pupils back in school
item.description: The reopening of primary school for all year groups is to be ditched by the government.

item.title: George Floyd: Boris Johnson urges peaceful struggle against racism
item.description: The prime minister says the death of George Floyd awakened an anger and an "undeniable feeling of injustice".

item.title: George Floyd murder suspect Derek Chauvin has bail set at $1.25m
item.description: Ex-policeman Derek Chauvin is accused of murdering the unarmed black man by kneeling on his neck.

item.title: George Floyd: Black Lives Matter protests go global
item.description: People in New Zealand, Canada, London and Germany are protesting in support of Black Lives Matter.

item.title: Coronavirus: Wider school reopening dropped and university dilemma
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this morning.

item.title: Britain goes coal free as renewables edge out fossil fuels
item.description: On Wednesday, Britain will mark two months without burning any coal to generate power.

item.title: Prince Andrew 'falsely portraying himself as willing', US prosecutor claims
item.description: US attorney claims Prince Andrew has "repeatedly declined" requests to schedule an interview.

item.title: KKK 'leader' charged for attack on Black Lives Matter protesters
item.description: A hate crime investigation is underway after a Virginia man allegedly drove his car into protesters.

item.title: Legal aid: Woman in abuse case challenges rules
item.description: She cannot claim legal aid because there is equity in the home she owns with her ex-partner.

item.title: North Korea halts all communications with South in row over leafleting
item.description: North Korea announces it will cut all official communication channels with South Korea from Tuesday.

item.title: Border Force staff 'will face violence' when fingerprinting migrants
item.description: UK Border Force workers in France will get hurt as a result of a government order, a union says.

item.title: Bonnie Pointer: Former Pointer Sisters singer dies aged 69
item.description: Bonnie Pointer was an original member of the group, best known for the hit Jump (For My Love).

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Prince Andrew and US 'at war' over Epstein inquiry
item.description: Tuesday's papers include the duke's clash with US prosecutors, and action after UK anti-racism protests.

item.title: Coronavirus: The Sikh community kitchen feeding thousands
item.description: One of the UK's largest Sikh temples has reinvented itself as an emergency food operation.

item.title: Coronavirus: Transiting Europe's eerily quiet airports
item.description: BBC Europe correspondent Jean Mackenzie has documented her flight back to the UK.

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: The shortlist and category winners for the 2020 Sony World Photography Awards Open competition.

item.title: Climate Basics: CO2 explained
item.description: CO2 is at the heart of our changing climate. Here's why.

item.title: If it ain't broke: You share your oldest working gadgets
item.description: People share the oldest gadgets they still use, via social media.

item.title: Fitzwilliam Museum masterpieces reimagined with face masks
item.description: The Fitzwilliam creates "a unique perspective on our current lives through the art we know and love".

item.title: Why this doctor's phone is her coronavirus helpline
item.description: Junior doctor Lisa Linpower describes how vital her phone has been during the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: George Floyd death: 'We have a pandemic of black people dying every day'
item.description: Two young organisers of the weekend's protests tell BBC theirs is the generation to bring real change.

item.title: The only disease right now is racism, says Sterling
item.description: England forward Raheem Sterling backs protests taking place across the UK, saying "the only disease right now is the racism that we are fighting".

item.title: ‘He wasn’t partying with the angels, he was dead’
item.description: A community worker describes the repercussions of suicide on young people from a deprived area of Belfast.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'We started going out in the first week of lockdown'
item.description: Sarah and Tom began a relationship in lockdown - they're now sharing bottles of sanitizer instead of wine.

item.title: The black British history you may not know about
item.description: From the black Britons in Roman times, to Henry VIII's trumpeter and our very own bus boycott.

item.title: George Floyd death: Why US protests are so powerful this time
item.description: There have been many Black Lives Matter protests before, but things seem different this time. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: How Covid-19 has changed the 'big fat Indian wedding'
item.description: Can simple intimate ceremonies be the new normal in a country obsessed with lavish weddings?

item.title: How backpacking towns are coping after being left empty by coronavirus
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has "decimated" backpacker towns like Queenstown, Cusco and Arugam Bay.

item.title: The treasure trove hidden in discarded computers
item.description: Recycled rare earth magnets are one solution to the rising demand for minerals used in our tech.

item.title: A surprise lockdown apology from my ex
item.description: Have the long hours of isolation during coronavirus lockdown led people to reflect on failed relationships?

item.title: Telling my brother's Windrush scandal story as a TV drama
item.description: The TV drama Sitting in Limbo follows Anthony Bryan, who was almost deported after 50 years in the UK.

item.title: Arriving passengers: 'Quarantine is like a staycation'
item.description: Passengers arriving at Stansted Airport speak about how the new quarantine rules have affected them.

item.title: Raheem Sterling calls for more BAME coaches and leaders in British football
item.description: Progress in the fight against racism will only come in football when more black players become managers, England and Manchester City forward Raheem Sterling says.

item.title: Lewis Hamilton: 'Remove all racist symbols'
item.description: Lewis Hamilton has urged countries around the world to remove "racist symbols" following the toppling of the statue of a slave trader in Bristol.

item.title: Fundraising, trash-talking & on-court fan chats - tennis is back but not as you know it
item.description: With the ATP and WTA tours on hold until at least August, the leading players are looking to keep sharp in domestic tournaments taking place around the world.

item.title: Premiership rugby clubs to cut salary cap by £1.4m
item.description: Premiership clubs unanimously agree to cut the salary cap by £1.4m to help with the losses incurred due to coronavirus.

item.title: 'I salute those who have, but athletes shouldn't have to fix racism' - Sport England's Grant
item.description: It is not the "job" of professional athletes to "fix the systemic problem" of racism in sport, says Sport England board member Chris Grant.

item.title: I was called 'bling' because I was black - ex-England defender Richards
item.description: Former England defender Micah Richards says he was unfairly labelled as someone who flaunted his wealth during his career because of his race.

item.title: Will Fulham catch top two? Can Jones pull Luton to safety? The Championship games to look out for
item.description: With the Championship set to return on 20 June, BBC Sport picks out the must-watch matches from the final nine rounds.

item.title: Can thermal cameras help spot coronavirus?
item.description: The devices allow a person's temperature to be checked from a distance, but are not always reliable.

item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.description: The pandemic has caused a record fall in energy investment and will likely lead to more pollution.

item.title: From the archives: How do you decide when a statue must fall?
item.description: We name buildings after people, or put up statues to them, because we respect them. But what if we discover they did wrong?
